title-group.article-title: Catalysis by allene oxide synthases (CYP74A and CYP74C): Alterations by the Phe/Leu mutation at the SRS-1 region

sec.title: N/A
sec.p:
Yana Y. Toporkova ∗
, Elena O . Smirnova, Lucia S . Mukhtarova, Svetlana S . Gorina,

Alexander N. Grechkin
∗∗
Kazan Institute of Biochemistry and Biophysics, FRC Kazan Scientific Center, Russian Academy of Sciences, P. O . Box 30, Kazan, 420111, Russia
A R T I C L E I N F O

sec.title: Keywords:
sec.p:
Lycopersicon esculentum Physcomitrella patens Linum
usitatissimum CYP
74 family Site-directed mutagenesis Allene oxide synthase Epoxyalcohol synthase Oxylipins
A B S T R A C T

sec.title: 1. Introduction
2.1. Preparation and purification of the recombinant WT LeAOS3,
sec.p: ZmAOS1, LuAOS, and PpAOS2 and their mutant forms

The open reading frames (ORFs) of LuAOS (CYP74A1; GenBank P48417.1) and PpAOS2 (CYP74A8; GenBank XP_024372097.1) genes consisted of 1608 and 1425 nucleotides, respectively, and encoded 536 and 475 amino acid polypeptides, respectively. The ORFs have been cloned into the NdeI and XhoI restriction sites of the pET-23a vector (Novagen, USA ) using primer pairs LuAOScF/LuAOScR and PpAOS2cF/ PpAOS2cR ( Table 1 ), respectively, to yield the recombinant target proteins with His-tags at C-termini.

The following Phe/Leu mutant forms of AOSs were obtained by site-directed mutagenesis using the primers listed in Table 1 : LeAOS3 F 108 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , LuAOS F 155 L , and PpAOS2 F
93 L .
Multiple alignment of the target region of the CYP74 enzymes is presented in Fig. 1 . The recombinant WT enzymes and their mutant forms have been obtained in heterologous expression systems using
E. coli
cells. His-tagged recombinant WT proteins and their mutant forms were obtained and purified for biochemical characterisations.

sec.title: 2.2. Analysis of reaction products of the WT enzymes
sec.p: In connection with the main aim of this work and for comparison with the WT enzymes, the mutant forms of studied AOSs were obtained and their catalytic properties were studied. The results are described in the following sections.

sec.title: 2.3. Analysis of reaction products of the LeAOS3 F 108L mutant form
sec.p:
For further elucidation of the effect of Phe/Leu substitution, the following mutant forms of other AOSs were obtained: PpAOS2 F 93 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , and LuAOS F
155 L .
The catalytic properties of these mutant forms towards fatty acid hydroperoxides are described below.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 2.4. Product specificities of the PpAOS2 F93L mutant form

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The WT PpAOS2 (data not illustrated) behaved as the specific AOS and produced mainly the α− ketols. In contrast, the mutant form PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form failed to produce any α− ketol upon incubations with 9( S )-HPOT ( Fig. 4B ) and 9( S )-HPOD ( Fig. 5B ). Instead, the predominant product 11 and the minor product 5 were formed from 9( S )-HPOT, while 9( S )-HPOD conversion led to products 4 and 12 . The mass spectrum of compound 11 possessed M+at m/z 396 (0.2%), [M + – Me] at m/z 381 (0.6%), [M + – MeO] at m/z 365 (0.1%), [M + – MeCH 2 CH = CHCH 2 ] at m/z 327 (14%), m/z 311 (12%), [327 – TMSOH] + at m/z 237 (18%), [M + – C10/C18] at m/z 185 (43%), [ CH 2 =O + -SiMe 3 ] at m/z 103 (27%), m/z 75 (50%), [SiMe 3 ] + at m/z 73 (100%). The spectrum approved the structure of the oxiranyl vinyl carbinol (EAS product) 9,10-epoxy-13-hydroxy-11,15-octadecadienoic acid (Me/TMS) for compound 11 . Compound 11 was represented by two epimers 11a (major) and 11b (minor), having the identical spectral patterns. The spectrum of product 5 exhibited M + at m/z 396 (0.2%), [M + – Me] at m/z 381 (0.4%), [M + – MeO] at m/z 365 (0.1%), [M + – TMSOH] + at m/z 306 (2.5%), [M + – C1/C8] at m/z 239 (3%), [M + – C1/C10] at m/z 197 (23%), m/z 131 (32%), [197 – TMSOH] + at m/z 107 (65%), [SiMe 3 ] + at m/z 73 (100%). The fragmentation patters, particularly the fragment at m/z 197, indicated the presence of a secondary alcohol moiety at C11 and overall the structure of the oxiranyl carbinol 9,10-epoxy-11-hydroxy-12,15-octadecadienoic acid (Me/TMS) – also EAS product – for product 5 . Thus, both products 11 and 5 are the epoxyalcohols – EAS products.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: a tr., trace quantity (less than 1% of total products).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: b No activity.

sec.title: Orphanage
Orphanage
sec.p: The results of incubations of the PpAOS2 F93 L mutant form with 13- hydroperoxides are discussed in the Supplementary Results. Briefly, while the mutant form mainly exhibited the EAS activity towards 9- hydroperoxides, 13-hydroperoxides conversion by this mutant form was less specific. The 13( S )-HPOD was converted mainly to the HPL products, less to the AOS products and least of all to the EAS products ( Table 2 ). The 13( S )-HPOT conversion went mainly to the AOS products, less to the HPL products, while the EAS products were only minorities ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 2.5. Product specificities of the ZmAOS1 F95L mutant form

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The WT ZmAOS1 behaved as the specific AOS and produced the corresponding α− ketols ( Figs. 4A and 5A , Supplementary Fig. S1 , Supplementary Fig. S2 ). These α− ketols turned into the pairs of corresponding diastereomeric vic -diols upon their NaBH 4 reduction. The F95L mutation of ZmAOS1 did not completely impair the AOS activity. The mutant form still produced significant amount of α− ketols (detected as their NaBH 4 reduction products, vic -diols) upon its incubations with 9( S )-HPOT ( Fig. 4C ) and 9( S )-HPOD ( Fig. 5C ). At the same time, the ZmAOS1 F95 L mutant form also produced the oxiranyl carbinols 4 ( Fig. 5C ) and ( Fig. 4C ) – EAS product, as well as compound 13 – 9-hydroxynonanoic acid, HPL product.

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: The specificity exhibited by the ZmAOS1 F95 L mutant form towards the 13-hydroperoxides is discussed in the Supplementary Results. Briefly, while the mutant form mainly exhibited the AOS activity towards 9-hydroperoxides, 13-hydroperoxides were converted mainly to the HPL products, accompanied by minor AOS and EAS products ( Table 2 ).

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: 2.6. Product specificities of the LuAOS F155L mutant form

sec.title: Orphanage
sec.p: In contrast to the above described mutant forms, the LuAOS F155 L mutant form did not show any qualitative alterations of catalytic activity compared to the wild type protein (data not presented). Conversion of 9( S )-HPOD, 9( S )-HPOT, 13( S )-HPOD, and 13( S )-HPOT by the LuAOS F155 L mutant form specifically afforded the corresponding α- ketol. The 13( S )-HPOT conversion besides with the α- ketol led to the cyclopentenone 12-oxo-10,15-phytodienoic acid, which is also the AOS product. Neither the HPL, DES nor EAS products were detected (results not presented).

sec.title: 3. Discussion
sec.p: To reveal the significance of the F / L toggle for allene oxide synthase catalysis, the mutant forms LeAOS3 F 108 L , ZmAOS1 F 95 L , LuAOS F 155 L , and PpAOS2 F 93 L were obtained and their catalytic specificities were examined. In contrast to the WT enzymes, which behaved as the specific AOSs, most of these mutant forms exhibited altered catalysis.

sec.title: 4.1. Materials
sec.p:
Flax plants (
L. usitatissimum
L ., cv. Novotorzhski) were grown in the fields near Kazan in summer 2017. The protonema of
P. patens
was grown on Knop medium (
) in 1 L pots in a growth chamber with a 16 h/8 h light/dark cycle at 22 ̊ C .

The pET-23a vector containing the open reading frame (ORF) of LeAOS3 gene was kindly provided to us by G. Howe. The ORF of ZmAOS1 gene was cloned by us in the рЕТ-32 Ek/LIC vector (Novagen, USA ) (
).

sec.title: 4.2. Preparation of recombinant enzymes
sec.p:
Cloning of LuAOS (CYP74A1; GenBank P48417.1) and PpAOS2 (CYP74A8; GenBank XP_024372097.1) genes were performed using primers listed in Table 1 and pET-23a vector (Novagen, USA ). The total RNA was isolated from photosynthesising organs (stems and leaves) of 21 days old flax plants, as well as from 14 days old protonema of
P. patens
. The resulting constructions, as well as plasmids containing ORFs of LeAOS3 and ZmAOS1 genes were transferred into
Escherichia coli BL
21 (DE3)pLysS strain cells (Novagen, USA ). The recombinant wildtype enzymes and their mutant forms were obtained as follows. An overnight culture (10 mL) of bacteria was inoculated into 1 L of Luria-Bertani medium supplemented with one volume of mineral medium M 9. Bacteria were grown at 37 ̊ C , 250 rpm to an OD 600 of 0.6. Expression of the target genes was induced by addition of 0.5 mM isopropyl-β- D-1-thiogalactopyranoside to the medium. Simultaneously, the medium was supplied with 5-aminolevulinic acid to facilitate the haem formation. Inductions were controlled by the 12% SDS-PAGE analysis of crude cellular extracts. Bacteria were harvested by centrifugation for 15 min at 4500 rpm at 4 ̊ C and lysed with BugBuster Protein Extraction Reagent (Novagen, USA ). Purification of His-tagged recombinant proteins was performed using Bio-Scale Mini Profinity IMAC cartridge in BioLogic LP chromatographic system (Bio-Rad, USA ). The recombinant enzymes were eluted from the cartridge using 50 mM histidine. The recombinant protein concentrations were determined using the Quant-iT™ Protein HS Assay Kit (Invitrogen, USA ). The haemoprotein concentrations were estimated using the pyridine haemochromogen assay (
). The relative purity of recombinant proteins was estimated by SDS-PAGE and staining of the gel with Coomassie brilliant blue R-250. Enzymatic activities of the purified recombinant enzymes were determined by monitoring the decrease of the signal at 234 nm in a РВ 2201 В spectrophotometer (Solar, Belarus ) with 40 μM substrate concentration. The analyses were performed in 0.6 ml of Na-phosphate buffer (100 mM, pH 7.0) at 25 ̊ C .

sec.title: 4.3. Bioinformatics methods and site-directed mutagenesis
sec.p:
The positioning of “ F / L toggle” in spatial structures of target CYP74s was performed using 3D models obtaining by ESyPred3D program (
) and the available X-ray models for allene oxide synthases (CYP74A) of
A. thaliana ( Lee et al., 2008 )
and
Parthenium argentatum ( Li et al., 2008 )
as the reference 3D structures.

The mutant forms of LeAOS3 , ZmAOS1 , LuAOS , and PpAOS2 genes were constructed by PCR using the primers listed in Table 1 and Pfu DNA polymerase (Promega, USA ). The mutations were confirmed by DNA sequencing using the 3130 Genetic Analyzer (Applied Biosystems, USA ).

sec.title: 4.4. Incubations of recombinant enzymes with fatty acid hydroperoxides
4.5. GC-MS analyses
sec.p:
Products were analysed by GC-MS as described before (
). The GC-MS analyses were performed using a Shimadzu QP5050A mass spectrometer connected to Shimadzu GC-17A gas chromatograph equipped with a Supelco MDN-5 S (5% phenyl 95% methylpolysiloxane) fused capillary column (length, 30 m ; ID 0.25 mm ; film thickness, 0.25 μm). Helium at a flow rate of 30 cm /s was used as the carrier gas. Injections were made in the split mode using an initial column temperature of 120 ̊ C , injector temperature 230 ̊ C . The column temperature was raised at 10 ̊ C /min until 240 ̊ C . The electron impact ionisation (70 eV) has been used.

sec.title: Acknowledgments
sec.p: Studies of ZmAOS1 F 95 L were carried out under financing from the Russian Science Foundation (Project No.16-14-10286). Studies of PpAOS2 F 93 L and LeAOS3 F 108 L were carried out with the financial support from the Russian Foundation for Basic Research (projects 16- 34-60231 and 18-04-00508, respectively). Studies of LuAOS F 155 L were supported by grant MK-5989.2018.4. Bioinformatics studies were carried out with the financial support from the government assignment for FRC Kazan Scientific Center of RAS.

sec.title: Appendix A. Supplementary data
sec.p: Supplementary data to this article can be found online at https:// doi.org/10.1016/j.phytochem.2019.112152.
